title: 111_hr1808
content: The "Clean Car Rebate Act of 2009" allows for a consumer rebate on purchases of certain new passenger motor vehicles. Tax credits are provided for qualified vehicles placed in service by the taxpayer in the taxable year. The applicable amount varies based on the taxable year, with specific amounts outlined in a table for the year 2009. The "Clean Car Rebate Act of 2009" provides tax credits for qualified vehicles based on their miles per gallon rating. The applicable amount varies depending on the mpg range, with specific amounts outlined in a table for the years 2009 and 2010. The "Clean Car Rebate Act of 2009" provides tax credits based on the miles per gallon rating of qualified vehicles. The applicable amount ranges from $0 to $2,500 depending on the mpg. After 2010, tables will be prescribed to determine the applicable amount to create consumer demand for fuel-efficient vehicles by 2015. The "Clean Car Rebate Act of 2009" offers tax credits for fuel-efficient vehicles to meet or exceed corporate average fuel economy requirements by 2020. The total revenue foregone to the Treasury in a calendar year from the credits should not exceed a specified limit. The term 'qualified vehicle' refers to a motor vehicle subject to fuel economy standards, with original use by the taxpayer, acquired for personal use, and made by a manufacturer. Definitions include 'miles per gallon rating' and 'motor vehicle'. The credit allowed for a qualified vehicle under subsection (a) will be reduced by any advance payments received under section 6431. The basis of property eligible for the credit will be decreased by the credit amount allowed. Coordination with sections 30B and 30D states that the credit allowed under subsection (a) is in addition to any credit allowed under section 30B or 30D for a qualified vehicle used by a tax-exempt entity. The taxpayer placing a vehicle in service must disclose the credit amount allowable without certain restrictions. No credit is allowed for property used outside the US or under section 179. Regulations will recapture credits for ineligible property. The taxpayer must meet certain eligibility criteria to claim a credit for a vehicle, including compliance with Clean Air Act provisions. If the taxpayer chooses not to apply this section to the vehicle, no credit will be allowed. The section discusses the termination of certain provisions related to Clean Air Act and motor vehicle safety regulations for properties purchased after December 31, 2014. Additionally, it mentions the advance payment of credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Consumer rebate available for purchases of new passenger motor vehicles. The Secretary will establish a program to make payments to certified individuals for qualified vehicles. A certified individual holds a qualified passenger motor vehicle eligibility certificate. The Secretary will refund any overpayment promptly. The Secretary may issue regulations for implementing the program to make payments to certified individuals for qualified vehicles, including reporting requirements and verification methods.
